hedline.hl1: A Caramoor Cabaret In Honor of Mothers

abstract.p: Robert Sherman column on upcoming musical events in Westchester County, NY, including Mother's Day event at Caramoor (M)

block.p: AT Caramoor in Katonah, Mother's Day is being observed today starting at 2 P.M. with the opening of an exhibition of costumes from the collection of Lucie and Walter Rosen, the original owners of the estate. Then at 3 P.M. the singer-pianist Larry Woodard offers a cabaret show of ''Songs for Mothers and Others.'' After the musicale, listeners are promised a lavish tea amid ''the regal splendor'' of the Italian Pavilion. Admission is fairly regal, too: $50, $25 for children under 16.

More modestly appointed recitals are also on today's schedule. At 1 P.M. the Meridian String Quartet brings music by Schumann, Shostakovich and Juan Arriaga, the precocious Spanish composer who died in 1826, 10 days before his 20th birthday, to Lyndhurst in Tarrytown. Later in the afternoon the young Chinese pianist Ren Zhang plays at the Sundays at 5 series at Wainwright House in Rye, offering works by Scarlatti, Schubert, Liszt and Godowsky.

At the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx today at 3 P.M., the Bronx Arts Ensemble will play Arthur Bird's ''Suite in D,'' Robert Baksa's ''Woodwind Octet'' and Mozart's ''Serenade for 13 Wind Instruments'' under the direction of Johannes Somary. The number to call for directions is (718) 601-7399.

Next weekend brings two more recitals in the Performers of Westchester cycle, a private home in White Plains being the site for the violin-piano duo of Nick Eanet and Nelson Padgett. Sonatas by Grieg, Brahms and Debussy are the offerings on Friday at 8:30 P.M. and again next Sunday at 4 P.M. Call 693-9658 for reservations.

The New Choral Society of Central Westchester tackles Beethoven's Mass in C and, with the pianist Andrew Armstrong, the ''Choral Fantasy'' next Saturday at 8 P.M. and next Sunday at 3 P.M. at Hitchcock Presbyterian Church in Scarsdale. The vocal soloists are Christine Goerke, Misoon Ghim and William Burden. For information, call 725-1678.

The Performing Arts Center at Purchase College closes its 20th-anniversary season with two major presentations. Next Friday at 8 P.M. the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Company has four pieces, all created by Mr. Jones, on its dance card, and next Saturday at 8 P.M. the soprano Jessye Norman appears with the pianist Ken Noda, singing Ravel's ''Five Popular Greek Melodies,'' Richard Danielpour's ''Spirits in the Well'' -- to a text by Toni Morrison -- and several songs by Richard Strauss.

Both of these evenings have preceding ''Prelude'' events at 7: Friday's guest speaker is Elizabeth Zimmer, dance critic of The Village Voice; next Saturday, Paul Robeson Jr. offers spoken and film recollections of his father in this centennial year of Robeson's birth. For tickets or more information, call the box office at 251-6200.

May is Asian History Month, and Westchester Community College is marking the occasion next Saturday at 8 P.M. with a program in the Academic Arts Theater that brings together members of two international troupes, Lotus Music and Dance and the Chinese Folk Dance Company. They will offer storytelling, costumes and movement illuminating the cultural diversity of India, Myanmar and China. There is also a free dance workshop next Saturday at 2 P.M. in the Student Center Lounge to which spectators, novices and dancers are welcome. For more details, call 785-6262.

The Noonday Getaway concert on Wednesday at 12:35 P.M. at Grace Episcopal Church in White Plains also focuses on music of India. Anindya Bose and Tappan Modak at sarod and tabla, respectively, improvise on semiclassical tunes derived from Indian folk music. For information, call 949-0384.

The prize-winning Meliora Winds offer an introduction to concert going, aimed at children 8 to 18, next Saturday at 7 P.M. at Caramoor. The fun actually begins at 6 P.M. with a preconcert session at which members of the quintet will coach groups of high school players. The box office number is 232-1252.

What sounds like another interesting family event is the re-creation of the old-time Pinkster Festival next Saturday and Sunday from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. at Philipsburg Manor in Sleepy Hollow. Burns Patterson of Historic Hudson Valley, which sponsors the festival, said it is ''a colorful explosion of music, dance and revelry, a historic cross-cultural carnival celebrating the region's early 18th-century African and Dutch heritage and traditions.'' Included are dance demonstrations, storytelling and music on traditional African instruments. For reservations, call 631-3992.
American Jazz, folk and country traditions are also being explored next weekend.

On Friday at 8:30 P.M. there will be a Louisiana dance party with the Cajun fiddler Michael Doucet and the Savoy-Doucet Band at the Woman's Club of White Plains, preceded at 7:30 by a free dance workshop. Call (718) 479-4936 for details.

Also on Friday at 8:30 P.M. a gala jazz evening at Purchase College, headlined by the percussionist Max Roach and the Roy Hargrove Sextet, concludes a day of jazz that ticket holders can attend without additional charge, including a student jazz workshop at 4, a talk about the career of Max Roach by the jazz historian and radio personality Phil Schaap at 7 and student big-band performances led by Richard De Rosa at 8. For more details, call 761-3715 or 251-6200.

Next Saturday at 8 P.M. the singer-songwriter Susan Werner from Philadelphia shares the stage of the Treestar Coffeehouse in the Northern Westchester Center for the Arts in Mount Kisco with a group called New Middle Class. The number to call to obtain more information is (860) 355-5946.

Twin Cloud Concerts is bringing two shows to the 1,200-seat F.D.R. Theater of the Veterans Affairs Medical Center in Montrose. Next Saturday at 8 P.M. it is the jazz-fusion group Spyro Gyra, and next Sunday at 7:30 P.M., Alison Krauss and her group Union Station offer country bluegrass. For tickets to either concert, call 424-8361.
